captions.text:
Hey, who remembers PlayStation All-Stars Battle 
Royale? Oh, Jesus. Sorry, I should have given you

more warning. Here, use this bucket to collect 
your spontaneously projected vomit. Basically,

someone high up at Sony, probably dressed like 
Emperor Palpatine, looked at the success of

Nintendo&#39;s Smash Bros games and said, &quot;Hey, 
we&#39;ve got a bunch of exclusive IPs as well,

why don&#39;t we make a game like that?&quot; And then 
one of their minions with a hunchback and a

Peter Lorre voice said, &quot;Yes, master, it&#39;s 
just that, one, Nintendo have a much wider

and more diverse range of characters, and about 
half the cast of our game is just going to be

realistically proportioned white dudes, and 
two, Nintendo have this inbuilt &#39;one big,

happy-clappy family&#39; dynamic that we can&#39;t 
really replicate because we&#39;re evil, emotionless,

corporate shitheads, and any attempt we make is 
going to have a strong vibe of forced bonhomie

akin to one of those face-saving family 
photoshoots politicians do after they get

caught with a male prostitute in a dollar store 
bathroom.&quot; At which point the Sony higher-up

zoned back in and said, &quot;So, what you&#39;re 
saying is we need to rip off a different

Nintendo game.&quot; And that, I assume, is 
the process that led us to Astro Bot.

Astro Bot is a new PS5 exclusive, which is 
rather unusual in this day and age in that

it&#39;s a mascot platformer, and most of those went 
the way of Betamax in the 32-bit era. A mascot

platformer in about the most blatant sense as well 
in that it&#39;s literally about a little Sony mascot

piloting a giant, sentient PS5 through space 
who gets antagonized by a generically evil,

big, green alien who is presumably still 
very mad about lack of retail availability,

and so we have to go through a bunch of 
platforming levels reassembling the PS5&#39;s

components and rescuing a whole bunch of 
other little robots, about half of whom are

cosplaying as characters from PlayStation 
games. So, for example, in one level,

we might find a little robot dressed like 
Ellie from The Last of Us, and once rescued,

they hang around in the home base, mimicking some 
iconic action made by Ellie, such as stabbing a

heavily pregnant woman to death. The characters 
are always referred to by coy nicknames,

and the games they&#39;re from are never identified, 
which on the one hand let me flex my know-it-all

gaming insider stiffie by identifying the 
more obscure references like Vib-Ribbon

and Incredible Crisis, but on reflection, I 
wonder if this might&#39;ve been a legal necessity.

Sony&#39;s tacit claim of ownership is a bit 
questionable on some of these. A bot dressed

like Lara Croft? A bot dressed like Ryu from 
Street Fighter? And then, of course, there&#39;s the

entire game being dressed like Super Mario Galaxy. 
&quot;And there it fucking is,&quot; sing the Sony fanboys.

&quot;Another biased reviewer dismissing it as a Mario 
Galaxy ripoff. Cuh, I expected better.&quot; Okay,

explain how it&#39;s different to Mario Galaxy, Sony 
fanboys. &quot;Uhhhhhh, downvote, downvote.&quot; Look,

let me put my memory cards on the table, okay? 
Astro Bot is a very good game. Shocked scream;

all heads turn; someone drops a glass. 
It seems to be a rare case of something

actually benefiting from corporate backing 
in that it spent all the money that got

pumped into it hiring world-class, talented 
people who know what the fuck they&#39;re doing,

not paying for the executive producer&#39;s three 
forced abortions. It&#39;s a highly polished, fun,

frolicsome platformer with intuitive controls, 
varied gameplay fueled by different traversal

methods, pitch perfect sound and music 
design, and highly advanced graphics tech,

to the point that there were moments when even 
a jaded, malicious patch of embittered dungeon

slime like myself could occasionally go, &quot;Gosh, 
that&#39;s actually rather impressive, splurp splurp.&quot;

I went out of my way to rescue every single 
bot in the game, partly because I was just

plain having fun, partly to see if there was 
one dressed like James Sunderland. And yet,

endemic fancy particle effects aside, the game 
comes across as terribly old-fashioned. Much

like Mario Galaxy itself, it feels like it 
came right out of the middle of the Wii era,

right down to the horrible controller gimmicks. 
Thankfully, the options menu let me turn off the

motion control bollocks, but it couldn&#39;t do 
anything about the bits where I was expected

to blow into the microphone, running the risk 
of someone coming into my office unannounced

and finding me attempting to orally stimulate 
my electronics. Do we really need a refresher

on this, Sony? Controller gimmicks do the 
opposite of immersion. They put a glowing

highlight on the fact that I am not an 
adorable squeaky robot saving the day,

I&#39;m a twat in a very cluttered office holding 
a massively overscoped lump of plastic. But

that really is my only issue, gameplay-wise. 
I might even like it more than Mario Galaxy.

The jumping physics aren&#39;t as nuanced, but at 
least you don&#39;t spend the whole time having

to listen to Charles Martinet making noises 
like he&#39;s getting rhythmically bollockstomped.

&quot;Oh my god, Yahtzee liked it; there&#39;s finally 
a reason to buy a PS5, alert the guard,

prep the parade horses!&quot; Hang on. Certain 
thoughts were nagging me about Astro Bot.

There&#39;s no escaping the fact that this is 
a fairly blatantly masturbatory exercise

on Sony&#39;s part. I mean, it&#39;s a game depicting a 
literal physical PS5 as a magical box of dreams,

in which every past and present contact in 
Sony&#39;s rolodex is forced to come out and

take a selfie with it, and, hey, I&#39;m not one 
to judge someone else for being masturbatory,

not without pangs of early-onset 
arthritis in my one good wrist,

but I wonder about the effectiveness of this as a 
marketing exercise. The overall statement, &quot;Hey,

isn&#39;t the PS5 great? It&#39;s got games like this one, 
primarily about how the PS5 is great,&quot; strikes me

as a bit of a circular argument. And Astro Bot 
did one thing for which I can never forgive it.

It made me make a spreadsheet. I know. I&#39;m gonna 
have to go back into therapy now. Having compiled

some data and checked through the PSN online 
store, I can now drop the following fact bomb:

Of the roughly 101 individual game IPs referenced 
in Astro Bot, 20% of them, fully one-fifth,

cannot be bought or played on the PS5 in any 
form. A vast majority of the remainder are only

playable thanks to PS4 backwards compatibility. 
You wanna know how many of the referenced games

strictly need a PS5 to play? Two. Two games. One 
game for every testicle in Sony&#39;s boardroom. Oh,

hang on, I forgot Returnal&#39;s on Steam now. 
One. One game. Half a game per bollock.

Astro Bot is good fun, but it&#39;s a celebration 
of Sony&#39;s past, not its present. I mean,

what&#39;s to celebrate? You gonna add any little 
bots dressed like Concord characters anytime

soon? Probably not, &#39;cos they&#39;d look like total 
bellends, but that&#39;s besides the point. It&#39;s

not gonna change the PS5&#39;s status in my house as 
mostly a dust-gathering machine grudgingly brought

out for an exclusive every six months or so. 
With Xbox having switched to making what amount

to gaming PCs that don&#39;t come with keyboards and 
Nintendo forever in its little bubble contentedly

smashing its toys together in what&#39;s basically 
a handheld with a loft conversion, Sony are in

the slightly sad position of trying to keep the 
console war going in the cutting-edge tech sector

when no one else bothered to show up. It&#39;s gotta 
feel like a fucking hollow victory. But if they&#39;re

gonna throw themselves a victory party, we might 
as well enjoy it. It&#39;s a fun party. Come along.

Have some good food. Listen to the band. Catch up 
with old friends. Just make sure you leave before

someone completely kills the mood by asking 
Cole MacGrath-bot what he&#39;s up to these days.
